timeline.bodyText:
An abstract class that has no implementation and no policy is really just like an interface. Can this, and its inner-Builder be interfaces, instead?
Interfaces are always better than abstract classes, since Java doesn't support multiple inheritence of classes, but you can implement as many interfaces as you want.
The only exception is when you have to use a class, because you want to enforce policy. And in that category:

Use a final class with composition. Don't need to worry about multiple inheritence - much less any inheritence, if the class is closed.
Use an abstract class that acts like an interface, but constrains what the extensible methods are able to achieve, through hard-coded policy.

timeline.bodyText:
Instead of doing this, It would be better to provide an overloaded method that does not require any options.
If your options as a user are to call:
void signIn(@Nullable first, @Nullable last, @Nullable options)

as:
signIn(null, null, null, ok -> {}, notOk -> {})

Wouldn't you rather have just done:
signIn(ok -> {}, notOk -> {})

The null params end up snaking down through the code base and creating a lot of branch complexity once everything has a if (thing == null)  around it.
So, the way I would handle this is to have two copies of sign-in, one that requires some non-null params, and one that does not take in those params, at all.
Internal to the implementation of the second method, choose "sane defaults." AuthSignInOptions.defaults() or something, that you can proxy into the other method, which does need the anon-null param.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: So I actually do have an overloaded method that does not require any options. I made this Nullable so the method that didn't take options could call this with null options since the options aren't the kind which take default values - they either exist or they don't. But if you feel strongly about this, I can have it pass a blank options object over to the other method instead and change this back to NonNull.

replies.bodyText:
In attempting to implement this here, I realized another class extending the base class can have options set which I don't have defined in this class and thus are not equal.
I'm going to stick with the stricter (and I think more traditional) definition that for two objects to be equal, they have to at least be the same class. I also don't think it provides value to the customer trying to create a broader definition of equal here even if we found a way to get around this technical issue.
